text: I chose silence, gripping the counter tightly as I watched the scene unfold.
But the drunk’s anger only grew hotter—like fire fed with oil.
He suddenly grabbed the bottle and smashed it against the floor. Shards and liquor scattered everywhere, forcing me back two steps under the blast.
The crowd gasped. The fire in the hearth shuddered, and the smell of spilled wine mixed with dust filled my lungs, making me cough.
The drunk’s fist was already raised—
At that instant, a gust of wind roared in from outside, snuffing out half the firelight.
The cloaked woman’s eyes were calm yet piercing. With a single motion of her hand, the shards and wind froze midair.
“That’s enough.”
The drunk froze, face turning pale as his throat rasped for breath.
His gaze fixed on the insignia gleaming faintly on her chest. His pupils widened in sudden recognition.
For a moment, silence. Then realization struck—his lips trembled, his breathing broke into panic.
“You... you’re—”
Before he could finish, he staggered backward as if struck by an invisible force.
He spun around in terror and practically tumbled out the door.
The door slammed shut behind him with a heavy thud. The tavern fell silent once more, leaving only the muffled whisper of snow outside.
I stayed leaning against the counter, chest heaving. A shallow cut traced across the back of my hand, gleaming red beneath the firelight.
She glanced at me—her gaze light as the wind, yet carrying a quiet, undeniable weight.
“Next time, try ducking when you see a bottle flying, will you?”
Her tone was calm, almost scolding—but with a faint trace of teasing beneath it.
I blinked, unsure how to reply, as she was already walking toward the door.
The wind seeped in again. She stopped, lifted a hand, and gently pushed the door shut.
“The wind’s calmed down,” she said, glancing back at me. “You can breathe now.”
She didn’t leave—just leaned lightly against the doorframe, as if making sure it was truly over.
